results.title: Anamorphic drawings
results.brief_description: Anamorphic illusions like these hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When you view them with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, and some are even made to unveil their images when you look from the right vantage point.

constellations_primary.name: Power and infamy
constellations_primary.description: Beginning with an anamorphic image of Napoleon III, this Constellation focuses on representations of the distorted perspective of patriarchal power.

results.description: Anamorphic illusions like these hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When you view them with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, and some are even made to unveil their images when you look from the right vantage point. Anamorphic drawings helped establish perspective in paintings, photography and special effects, and they also influenced the development of CinemaScope and widescreen in film.
description_for_label: Anamorphic illusions like these hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When you view them with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, and some are even made to unveil their images when you look from the right vantage point. Anamorphic drawings helped establish perspective in paintings, photography and special effects, and they also influenced the development of CinemaScope and widescreen in film.

results.title: Thaumatropes
results.brief_description: A thaumatrope is an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins.

constellations_primary.name: There's always a lighthouse
constellations_primary.description: The thaumatrope was an early optical illusion device popular in the Victorian era and was important to the development of the moving image.

results.description: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.
description_for_label: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.
